PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T., Feb. 27, 1883.

D. H. MACDOWALL, ESQ.,
PRINCE ALBERT.

SOUTH BRANCH, March 28, 1883.

We, the undersigned residents of the District of Lorne, having full confidence in your integrity and ability to represent us in the North West Council, hereby pledge ourselves to vote for you in support of your candidacy. We believe that your experience and qualifications will enable you to be an effective representative of our interests. We urge you to accept our support and vote for you at the coming election.

We are,

Yours respectfully,

Edward Taylor,
John H. Gordon,
George Tail,
William Thomas,
Philip Turner,
Patrick Anderson,
Francis Fournier,
George Whitford,
George F. Whitford,
John Atwood,
Adam Butler,
Robert Harper,
James B. Mack,
John Donald,
Peter Campbell,
Alexander Mitchell,
Jeremiah Stevens,
J. E. W. Brown,
Bernard Newmarch.

C. L. BRYDGES, Land Commissioner.
Sudden Death.

Wald was brought to death on Sunday morning by Mr. Joseph McPhail, who lives in Prince Albert. He was a neighbour of the man of Oliver, whose body was found near the latter's residence Saturday afternoon, by some neighbour named Mr. Porter. The body was carried into the deceased's house by Mr. Porter, and placed in the same place where it was found in the initial period. On Monday morning, Mr. Porter, accompanied by Mr. Oliver, went out with the other officers of the Lodge, to make a search for the missing member, to ensure him the particulars of the proceedings. It appears that the deceased had been suffering from an affection of the heart, and for that reason he had been sent to Mr. Porter. There seems to be no doubt that while engaged about his work, he fell down and died, which, as stated, proved fatal. The effects of the fall were immediately perceived in the members of the party present, who immediately called for assistance, but the deceased died entirely alone and without any apparent struggle. Mr. Porter will administer all affairs until his brother, Mr. John C. Oliver, number three, returns from the United States. The funeral of the late Mr. Oliver, who died at the age of thirty-three years, took place this afternoon at the Presbyterian Cemetery, with Masonic honours.

Items of Interest.

The German police have got possession of some of Hartmann's communications from Nitidus, which are now being subjected to the German censorship.

Mr. Macdonald has received correspondence touching leases or coal lands in the North West, and statements of payments made and amounts owing.

It is probable that during the session of the Legislature, the question of the extension of the Portage Westward will be discussed. Mr. Macdonald has written to the Secretary of State for Canada, expressing his opinion that the extension should be made.

The Echo House, Qu'Appelle.

The Echo House is situated on the banks of the Qu'Appelle River, about five miles from Prince Albert. It is a comfortable and well-kept establishment, and is highly recommended by those who have visited it.

Government House.

Government House is situated on the banks of the Qu'Appelle River, about five miles from Prince Albert. It is a comfortable and well-kept establishment, and is highly recommended by those who have visited it.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 28, 1883

COMMUNICATIONS.

The following will be seen in correspondence from Mr. Macdonald, who has been appointed to the position of Commissioner of Crown Lands. Mr. Macdonald has been appointed to the position of Commissioner of Crown Lands, and he will take up his duties at once. He will be responsible for the administration of the Crown Lands Act, and he will be assisted by a number of deputies.

THE COMING ELECTION.

To the Editor of the Times:

Sir,

I have received a number of communications from various parts of the country, and I am glad to see that there is a great deal of interest in the coming election. The question of the future of the Dominion is a very important one, and it is essential that we should all do our best to ensure a fair and just result. I would urge all my readers to vote, and to vote wisely.

Yours sincerely,

A. B. HALL.

TO THE ELECTORS OF THE Electoral District OF LORNE

Gentlemen—

Having been requested by a number of friends to offer myself as a candidate for the coming Election, I have respectfully declined, as I feel myself unequal to the task, and if returned, I pledge myself not to use any power to further the interests of Prince Albert and vicinity.

I remain, gentlemen,

your obedient servant,

A. B. PORTER, M.H.

Notice of Dissolution.

Notice is hereby given that the undersigned, Mr. Porter, M.H., has been elected to the office of Commissioner of Crown Lands, under the name of HURD & BAKER, have therefore dissolved by mutual consent, their business at Prince Albert, N.W.T., this day of March, 1883.

W. H. HURD.
